questions.question: Networking increases a computer's utility.
The Internet connects only thousands of computers.
Email messages are embedded in files transferred between computers.
An email address uniquely identifies a cyberspace mailbox.
Email messages are broken into packets.
Routers transfer packets from the sender’s mail server to the receiver’s mail server.
The network utility grows as the number of users squared.
As the number of people grows, the network may suffer overload.
People may act irresponsibly on the network.
The amount of email that is spam was 8% in 2001.
Spam became less effective over the years.
Sending spam emails is more expensive than traditional junk mail.
Spam can be profitable even if only 1 in 100,000 recipients buys the product.
Firms get email addresses only through opt-in lists.
Viruses gather email addresses from PCs address books.
Dictionary attacks are not used by spammers.
Spammers seek privacy using bots and zombies.
Changing email and IP addresses helps mask the sending machine.
Spam blockers attempt to screen out spam by blocking suspicious subject lines.
Capturing another insecure system is not used as a spam launch pad.
Does Trend Micro maintain a Blackhole List of IP addresses known for sending spam?
Does Trend Micro provide the Blackhole List for free to all organizations?
Can unsecured mail servers be mistakenly added to the Blackhole List?
Is the Blackhole List only used to block email from known spammers?
Does Trend Micro contact marketers who violate email standards?
Senders and receivers derive equal benefit from emails.
Blacklisting will reduce the benefits of internet utility as a whole.
Innocent users are used as a means for an end in Kantian evaluation.
Requiring an explicit opt-in of subscribers is a proposed solution to the spam epidemic.
Requiring labeling of email advertisements is not a proposed solution to the spam epidemic.
Email messages are practically free.
Profits decrease with the number of messages sent.
The internet design allows unfair, one-way communications.
The Web is centralized.
Every Web object has a unique address.
A central authority is needed to control the Web.
The web is based on the Internet.
A wiki is a type of website that does not allow editing by multiple users.
Blogs are typically maintained by individuals with regular entries of commentary.
The web does not require browsers to access content.
Shopping is one of the ways people use the web.
E-commerce is one of the uses of the internet mentioned in the text.
Everyone in the world has Internet access according to the text.
Saudi Arabia has a decentralized control center for internet access.
Germany forbids access to neo-Nazi sites.
The United States has made no efforts to limit minors' access to pornography.
Censorship is not mentioned in the text.
Government domination is a form of direct censorship.
Prepublication review is not a form of censorship.
Licensing and registration are used to control media with limited bandwidth.
Self-censorship is the most common form of censorship.
Self-censorship involves a group deciding not to publish material.
Maintaining good relations with government officials is important for journalists to keep their official sources of information.
Movies, TVs, CDs, and video games are universally accepted on the Web without any warnings.
The Internet poses challenges due to its many-to-many communication nature.
It is easier to close a radio station than to shut down an Internet site.
Millions of PCs are connected to the internet yearly.
There is a way to monitor all Web sites.
The internet extends beyond national borders.
An adult Web site can confirm the age of a user.
Kant supported censorship.
Mill opposed censorship.
The word 'infallible' translates to 'معصوم' in Arabic.
According to the text, any opinion (not the majority opinion) may contain a kernel of truth.
Mill’s Principle of Harm states that intervention is justified only to prevent harm to others, not for the individual’s own good.
The government must intervene when an individual’s act harms others.
In the 18th century, England and the colonies had prior restrictions on freedom of expression.
People could be punished for sedition or libel in 18th century England and its colonies.
American states did not adopt bills of rights including freedom of expression.
The 1st amendment to the U.S. Constitution addressed freedom of expression to discuss public issues.
Freedom of Expression is considered an absolute right.
The Amendment covers only political speech.
The right to freedom of expression must be balanced against the public good.
There are no restrictions on freedom of expression for the public good.
A ban of cigarette advertising on TV is an example of a restriction on freedom of expression.
Web filters are software that prevents display of certain Web pages.
Web filters can only be installed on individual PCs.
ISPs may provide web filtering services.
An Internet service provider (ISP) is a company that provides web access to both businesses and consumers.
ISPs only provide web access and no other services.
Maintaining a 'black list' of objectionable sites is one methodology used by ISPs.
Child Internet Protection Acts have never been implemented.
Identity theft is a form of breaking trust on the Internet.
Identity theft occurs when a person uses another person’s electronic identity.
More than 1 million Americans were victims of identity theft in 2008 due to their online activities.
Phishing is the use of email or Web pages to attempt to deceive people into revealing personal information.
A fake PayPal site asking you to disclose information because your card is about to expire is an example of phishing.
Chat room predators are individuals who support real-time discussions among many people.
Some pedophiles meet through chat rooms.
Police do not conduct sting operations in chat rooms.
The quality of web-based information is consistent.
Google maintains a database of 8 million web pages.
Ranking web pages does not involve any form of voting algorithm.
If many links point to a page, Google search engine ranks that page higher.
The traditional definition of addiction includes compulsive use of a harmful substance or drug.
Kimberly Young created a test for Internet addiction consisting of 8 questions about gambling on the Net.
Answering 'yes' to 5 questions in Kimberly Young's test means you are addicted to the Internet.
Kimberly Young's test for Internet addiction is widely accepted and uncontroversial.
Is peer group a social factor contributing to computer addiction?
Is stress a situational factor contributing to computer addiction?
Does lack of social support contribute to computer addiction?
Is limited opportunities for productive activity an individual factor?
Does a tendency to follow activities to excess contribute to computer addiction?
Is lack of achievement an individual factor in computer addiction?
Does fear of failure contribute to computer addiction?
Is a feeling of isolation a social factor?
